edge: The film and novel recount the story of a young white woman and aspiring journalist Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan. The story focuses on her relationship with two black maids, Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson, during the Civil Rights Movement in 1963 Jackson, Mississippi. In an attempt to become a legitimate journalist and writer, Skeeter decides to write a book from the point of view of the maids, exposing the racism they face as they work for white families. Black domestic workers in 1960s United States were referred to as "the help", hence the title of the journalistic exposé, the novel and the film.

The film and novel recount the story of a young white woman and aspiring journalist Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan. The story focuses on her relationship with two black maids, Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson, during the Civil Rights Movement in 1963 Jackson, Mississippi.
Black domestic workers in 1960s United States were referred to as "the help", hence the title of the journalistic exposé, the novel and the film.
In 1963, Aibileen Clark is an African-American domestic worker in Jackson, Mississippi, working for socialite Elizabeth Leefolt. She raises Elizabeth’s emotionally neglected two-year-old Mae Mobley.
Minny Jackson works for Mrs. Walters.
Hilly Holbrook, who leads the women's socialite group, and her mother Mrs. Walters.
Securing a local job writing a housekeeping column, she witnesses the city's systemic racism and the demeaning mistreatment of maids in Elizabeth Leefolt's household.
Elizabeth Leefolt has a two-year-old daughter named Mae Mobley who is neglected emotionally.
Hilly Holbrook tries to discourage Skeeter from pursuing her interest in writing a book about the experiences of African-American maids.
In the movie, 'The Help', Aibileen Clark is one of the central characters.
Elizabeth Leefolt's mother Mrs. Walters also appears in the movie, 'The Help'.
The antagonist of the story, Hilly Holbrook, tries to stop Skeeter from publishing her book on the experiences of African-American maids in 'The Help'.
Hilly insists on installing separate bathrooms and wants them enshrined in building code, implying a strong relation between the two concepts.
During a dangerous tornado, Minny defiantly uses an indoor bathroom, which results in her being fired by Hilly and rendered unemployable.
Hilly spreads the lie that Minny stole from her, forcing her teenage daughter to quit school to work, thereby vindictively rendering Minny unemployable.
Celia gratefully hires Minny as her house in Madison is massive, and she cannot cook, indicating a need for domestic help.
Celia does not tell Johnny, Hilly's former love interest, that she has hired Minny, implying a desire to keep this decision private from him.
Celia and the socialites ostracize Celia Rae Foote due to her being pregnant, highlighting the influence of social norms on their behavior.
Minny's husband has given her a black eye, which Celia treats.
Hilly's insistence on separate and equal bathrooms for blacks in the Junior League newsletter, which Skeeter slow-walked instead of publishing an embarrassing misprint.

Hilly refuses to advance money to Yule May, who needs it for her twins' education. When Yule May pawns a lost ring and is arrested after Hilly reports her, this incident inspires more maids to share their stories.
Aibileen agrees to let Skeeter interview her after attending a dynamic sermon.
Minny lets Skeeter interview her after going to a dynamic sermon.
Aibileen's son dies due to the negligence of his foreman after an on-the-job accident.
The assassination of Medgar Evers inspires more maids to share their stories.

After revealing the "terrible awful", Minny brings Hilly her famous chocolate pie but reveals – after Hilly had finished two slices – she had baked her own excrement into it. This incident leads to Hilly's mother being sent to a nursing home for laughing about it.
Elaine Stein asks Skeeter for many more maid's stories for the book, but fear of retribution prevents others from coming forward.
Skeeter confronts Charlotte about Constantine's departure.
During a Daughters of America luncheon at her home, Charlotte fired Constantine when Rachel refused to enter the house through the kitchen.
Rachel subsequently moved her heartbroken mother to Chicago,
Minny subtly reveals the 'terrible awful' to Celia, calling her 'Two Slice Hilly'.
Hilly threatens to sue Skeeter for libel,
Johnny tells Minny he knows she has been working at their house and promises her permanent job security,
Aibileen's congregation honors her for her leadership in the publication.
Emma Stone was attached to play the role of Eugenia 'Skeeter' Phelan in the production.
Viola Davis was cast as Aibileen for the production.
Bryce Dallas Howard was cast as Hilly Holbrook, a racist and town ringleader for the production.
Allison Janney was cast as Charlotte Phelan, Skeeter's mother for the production.
Chris Lowell was cast as Stuart Whitworth, Skeeter's boyfriend and a senator's son for the production.
Leslie Jordan appears as the editor of the fictional local newspaper, The Jackson Journal, in the production.
Mike Vogel plays the character Johnny Foote in the production.
Octavia Spencer portrays Minny in the production and inspired the character of Minny in Stockett's novel, as well as voiced her in the audiobook version.
The city of Greenwood was chosen to portray 1960s-era Jackson in the production, and producer Green said he had expected to shoot '95 percent' of the film there.

The Help was the most significant film production in Mississippi since O Brother, Where Art Thou? This highlights the significance of The Help as a movie and also emphasizes that it was filmed in Mississippi. Mississippi's significance is further highlighted by Stockett's statement about her heart being broken if the movie were set anywhere else.
Tate Taylor and others came to Greenwood to scout locations for The Help. This implies that Greenwood is a location where some parts of the movie were filmed.

At his first meeting with DreamWorks executives, Tate Taylor presented them with a photo album of potential filming spots in Greenwood. This shows that Greenwood was proposed as a location for filming The Help to DreamWorks executives.

The state's tax incentive program for filmmakers was a key enticement in the decision to shoot The Help in Mississippi. This suggests that the tax incentive program played an important role in convincing the producers to choose Mississippi as the location for filming.
Two soundtracks were released for The Help.
Geffen Records released the soundtrack album on August 4, 2011.
The soundtrack album was released on August 4, 2011.
The 12-track collection, collated by Jennifer Hawks,
The songs from the likes of Johnny Cash, Frankie Valli and Ray Charles.
Mary J. Blige's "The Living Proof" is the only original track.
Her raw emotions inspired her to compose the lone song for the film.
The score album, featuring original cues composed and conducted by Thomas Newman was released by Varèse Sarabande on September 6, 2011.
The film's release date was rescheduled two days earlier to August 10, 2011.
Distributed The Help worldwide through the studio's Touchstone Pictures banner.

The movie 'The Help' earned $169,708,112 in North America.
The amount earned by 'The Help' in North America is $169,708,112.
'The Help' earned $52,094,074 in other territories.
On its opening day (Wednesday, August 10, 2011), 'The Help' earned $5.54 million.

node_2: rise of the planet of the apes
edge: On its first weekend, 'The Help' grossed $26 million, coming in second place behind 'Rise of the Planet of the Apes'.
'The Help' topped the box-office charts for three consecutive weekends on its fourth weekend (Labor Day three-day weekend).
During its second weekend, 'The Help' jumped to first place with $20 million.
'The Help' crossed the $100 million mark on its 21st day of release in August 2011.
This was the longest uninterrupted streak since 'Inception' (35 days), which was also a late summer release, in 1999.
To promote the film, TakePart hosted a series of three writing contests.
TakePart hosted a recipe contest as part of promoting the film.
Rebecca Lubin won the recipe contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
Rebecca Lubin, a nanny from Mill Valley, California, won the recipe contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
Darcy Pattison won 'The Help' Children's Story Contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
TakePart hosted a children's story contest for 'The Help' to promote the film.
Guest judge Lou Berger chose Darcy Pattison's story in the 'The Help' Children's Story Contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
Genoveva Islas-Hooker shared a story about someone who inspired her in the contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
Genoveva Islas-Hooker's story was about a special individual named Confidential, who inspired her in the contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
Guest judge Doc Hendley was impressed by Genoveva Islas-Hooker's story about someone who inspired her in the contest hosted by TakePart to promote the film.
Review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes reported that 76% of 232 professional critics gave the film a positive review, with an average score of 7.00/10.
232 professional critics gave the film a positive review
Reported that 76% of 232 professional critics gave the film a positive review, with an average score of 7.00/10
Rises on the strength of its cast – particularly Viola Davis, whose performance is powerful enough to carry the film on its own.
Powerful enough to carry the film on its own.
Glosses over its racial themes
Appealing, entertaining, touching and perhaps even a bit healing, The Help is an old-fashioned grand yarn of a film, the sort we rarely get these days.
The Help will make you laugh, yes, but it can also break your heart. In the dog days of August moviegoing, that's a powerful recommendation.
Gives the film a score of 62 based on 41 reviews Indicating generally favorable reviews.
Roxane Gay of literary web magazine The Rumpus argues that the film uses racial Hollywood tropes like the Magical Negro character, which might be offensive to African Americans.
Discussed by Keli Goff in The Daily Beast in an article concerning white savior narratives in film.

Accused both the book and the film of insensitive portrayals of African-American vernacular, a nearly uniform depiction of black men as cruel or absent, and a failure to acknowledge the sexual harassment many black women endured in their white employers' homes.

Released an open statement criticizing the film, stating '[d]espite efforts to market the book and the film as a progressive story of triumph over racial injustice, The Help distorts, ignores, and trivializes the experiences of black domestic workers.'
Won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in this film.
Nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actress.
Nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress.
